title: Two women mistakenly issued the same Social Security number, resulting in identity mess

last_post.content:
A very Asian American nightmare: These two young immigrant women—both named Jieun Kim, one living in Los Angeles and one in Evanston, IL—were accidentally issued the same social security number by the SSA. Since then they’ve been denied credit, had bank accounts shut down, are in legal limbo when it comes to residency and officially, per the government, are one person with four biological parents.

title: Raise and spend money with full transparency.

last_post.content:
I’ve noticed a lot of instances are using #patreon to collect instance fees and donations. Patreon is shareholder owned. When you make payments through Patreon, 7% of your payment goes to Patreon, which ultimately goes to Patreon shareholders.

That’s not a model that suits the #fediverse. Here’s an alternative: use https://opencollective.com/. It’s a co-op, and it only charges 2%, which ultimately gets used to fund new #coops. Now, that’s a more #decentralised, fediverse-style model, isn’t it!

title: Extracting Training Data from Diffusion Models

last_post.content:
This time Google does the right thing - while shareholders grill them over "competition" with ChatGPT (not really...), they research and publish how useful and privacy preserving large models are.

It turns out, as suspected, they are not very useful for actual professional writers who understand "something" about writing: https://arxiv.org/abs/2211.05030

...and leak the dataset/private data, 2x worse with diffusion than GANs: https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.13188

No wonder Google is hesitant to use them. :)

title: StreetPass for Mastodon

last_post.content:
StreetPass is a cool new browser extension that uses Mastodon's verification system in a clever way.

Mastodon users verify themselves by adding a custom link to their personal site. StreetPass lets you know when you've found one of these links, and adds them to your list. As you browse the web, StreetPass will build a list of Mastodon users that belong to the websites you visit.

I spoke with the creater @tvler about the project, 🧵 below.

Visit https://streetpass.social/ to try it yourself!

title: sussex.ac.uk/library/news-even...

last_post.content:
@mara and I are doing a workshop on Queering Bash as part of the Sussex Humanitites Lab & Full Stack Feminism. It is free and you can register here: https://www.sussex.ac.uk/library/news-events-workshops?id=59758

//Queering Bash is a work-in-progress artistic/technical manual, focusing on learning code otherwise. This workshop will introduce the UNIX philosophy from a queer critical perspective, reimagining a human/computer relation that upsets the gendernormativity embedded in years of free software development. Bash is a command line interface and a scripting language developed in 1989 as a piece of free software for UNIX Systems (Linux and Mac OS but it has been also ported to Windows) and it is a very useful program for system administration, file management, generating reports and automating tasks. Bash was a replacement of two previous shells. Yet it has been ubiquitous in most of our world's servers and personal computers. [..] We are interested in subverting the prevailing norms of technology, namely efficiency, utility, and productivity within capitalistic logics, by coding otherwise.
//

title: predictive-optimization.cs.pri...

last_post.content:
These flaws don’t have tech fixes. So predictive optimization *fails on its own terms*. Any one of these flaws should make us question a decision making system. Together, they severely challenge legitimacy of predictive optimization applications.
We present a rubric with 27 questions for activists to contest these systems. But the burden should be on those who exercise power to justify their use. To this end, our rubric can also help developers analyze their applications. https://predictive-optimization.cs.princeton.edu/rubric.pdf

Findings:
(1) online reviews not only centred on reviewers’ experiences but include discussion of books' merits
(2) reviewers of suspense prefer plot & character; reviewers of literary books prefer style & story
(3) references to body often used describing positive reading experiences
(4) positive reviews recount story, negative reviews try to explain why book was disappointment

title: Learning-Rate-Free Learning by D-Adaptation

last_post.content:
https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07733
'Learning-Rate-Free Learning by D-Adaptation'
- Aaron Defazio, Konstantin Mishchenko

The informational complexity of optimising convex, Lipschitz functions depends on the distance of the initial state to the true minimiser, which is typically unknown in practice. This work presents an adaptive scheme for estimating this distance, and shows that the resulting algorithm is then essentially rate-optimal, up to log factors.

#sparxivdigest
